title: Feeding frequencies affect sensory quality, nutrition, physicochemical and structural characteristics of Macrobrachium rosenbergii sourced from rice-prawn co-culture system.
abstract: This study evaluated the effects of different feeding frequencies on the sensory, nutritional, and structural properties of Macrobrachium rosenbergii in a rice-prawn co-culture system, aiming to enhance feeding efficiency and provide a reference for consumer choice. Five feeding frequencies were designed: T0 (no feeding), T1 (once a day), T2 (every two days), T3 (every three days), and T4 (every four days). The feeding trial lasted 60 days while the rice was harvested after 150 days of transplanting. Results showed significant positive correlations between feeding frequency and hepatopancreas index, total edible yield, and condition factor, with the highest values in the T1 group. PUFA content decreased significantly with the decrease in feeding frequency. At lower feeding frequency, protein α-helix content decreased, β-sheet content increased, and higher carbonyl content indicated reduced antioxidant capacity. Entropy weight method evaluation identified T1 as optimal feeding frequency for comprehensive prawn quality metrics.
